newsitem.title: USA: Carey, reformer and fighter, in biggest battle yet.
newsitem.headline: Carey, reformer and fighter, in biggest battle yet.

text.p: Teamsters Union President Ron Carey fought great odds to get his job, waged a bitter battle to keep it and has sparred with his current opponent, United Parcel Service, for about 30 years.
But the 11-day-old strike by some 185,000 members of the 1.4 million-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters that has paralyzed package delivery giant UPS is Carey's biggest battle yet.

Carey, 61, who has urged the government not to intervene in the dispute by seeking a temporary back-to-work order, was able to capture the Teamsters' highest office in part because the government paved the way for him.

A long-time dissident and self-styled reformer in a union that for years symbolized labor corruption, Carey won its presidency in a government-supervised three-way race in late 1991 that was required as part of a settlement of a 1989 federal racketeering lawsuit against the union.

It was the first time in the union's 93-year history that a Teamster president was chosen by the rank and file instead of convention delegates and it gave Carey, the long-shot outsider in the race, the opportunity he had long sought.

A former Marine, the 5-foot, 10-inch Carey worked as a driver for UPS for 11 years until he was elected president in 1967 of Teamsters Local 804 in the New York City borough of Queens where he grew up.

There he represented mostly UPS workers who once staged a wildcat strike, kept his members covered by a contract that was separate from the nationwide agreement that is now in dispute and was always on the outs with the union's top brass in Washington.
A darling of union reformers inside and outside of the Teamsters, Carey used the 1991 three-way race to his advantage as his two "Old Guard" opponents split their vote and left him with a plurality.

Since winning office, Carey has taken a high-profile stand against corrpution -- three of his six predecessors went to prison -- and lavish spending. He sold the union's jet, cut his own salary and has put 72 Teamster locals into trusteeships, mostly after evidence of corruption was uncovered.
But he has made many enemies in the union along the way.
A three-week nationwide truck strike he led in 1994 left the union unable to pay strike benefits, and members rejected his proposed dues hike to fortify the treasury.
Late last year, he narrowly defeated James Hoffa, son and namesake of the notorious Teamsters president who was presumed murdered in 1975, in another government-supervised election.

But the bitterly fought election is now under a cloud. A federal grand jury in New York has been investigating the Carey campaign's fund-raising practices, and two campaign aides have been charged with fraud so far.
As a result, the court-appointed officer overseeing the election has not certified Carey as the winner and Hoffa has demanded a new election.

Carey was also an early supporter of the 1994 insurgent bid of John Sweeney to become president of the AFL-CIO. As president of the largest union in the 78-union federation, Carey's support was crucial for Sweeney's victory.
